msItem.author: Philip of Oxford
msItem.title: De miraculis sancte Frideswide

msItem.rubric: fol. 1ra Incipit prologus domni philippi prioris de miraculis sancte frideswide.
msItem.incipit: Domini ac saluatoris nostri uirtus et sapientia tanto maioribus laudum preconiis attollitur⸵
msItem.explicit: fol. 1vb ut ora sacerdotibus ostenderent preceptum est.

msItem.incipit: Scripturus itaque miracula que temporibus nostris
msItem.explicit: fol. 30rb nobis in tante uirtutis testimonium ostenderunt;
msItem.note: Two modern hands have numbered the sections implied by the drop capitals in ink and pencil, as chapters 1–98. A contemporary hand indicates nine readings within the text, each of which ends with the annotation Tu autem in the margin if it is not immediately followed by another lectio. Lectio 1, fols. 1vb–2ra, ch. 1, Scripturus itaque … tuorum super omnia aromata; 2, fols. 2vb–3rb, chs. 5–6, Cum igitur … remanerent uestigia; 3, fols. 3ra–4ra, ch. 8, Erat in uico quodam … ipsa rerum experientia didicimus; 4, fol. 4ra–va, chap. 9, Per idem tempus … et tedio affecerat inmanitas; 5, fols. 6vb–7va, chap. 20, Ad laudem insuper diuine pietatis … ubi munus curationis acceperat; 6, fols. 7vb–8rb, chap. 22, Hoc quoque relatu … prorsus et inmunem; 7, chap. 23, fols. 8rb–9ra, Sed et de hoc quod eodem die … reformante momentis; 8, fols. 9vb–10ra, Puella quedam Emelina nomine … et corpore herens et affectu (opening indicator erased); 9, fols. 15ra–va(?), Nec uacat a laude uirginis … sue testimonio roborantes (no Tu autem).
The manuscript’s organization of the text is not reflected in the Acta Sanctorum edition, whose text is unreliable.

listBibl.bibl: John Blair, ‘Saint Frideswide Reconsidered’, Oxoniensia 52 (1987): 71–127 (extract from the prologue at 118–19).

msItem.title: Acrostic on Frideswide
msItem.incipit: Fontem in sicco fundo a domino impetrauit

msItem.title: Words relating to the miracles of Frideswide set in hexameter, set against the seven vices

list.item:
Contra superbiam
Filia. Regalis. Iuris. Datur. Esse. Sodalis.
Venti. Venalis. Iacturam. Depulit. Alis.

Contra iram
Fons. Redit. Immemores. Ducunt. Exemplum. Sapores.
Vincunt. Vltores. Inuios. Dicentis. Amores.

Contra inuidiam
Fer. Ruit. Inuidie. Dampnabilis. Euse. Salutis.
Viscera. Virtutis. Iam. Dat. Amicicie.

Contra accidiam
Factoris. Recolens. Iusti. Deuocius. Egit.
Summa. Videre. Volens. Iuga. Dissuadentis. Abegit.

Contra auariciam
Fatales. Retum. Iactus. Despexit Egena
Sorte. virum. verum. Iustum. Dilexit. Amena.

Contra Gulam
Fauces. Restrinxit. In Deliciis. Epularum.
Sic. ventrem. vincit. Ita. Dulcoratus. Amarum.

Contra luxuriam
Nos. Redolens. Iuit. Ductor. Enigma. Sequta.
Virgula. Vestiuit. Imbres. Dilexit Acuta.

collation.signatures: The first leaf of each gathering is lettered a–d at the foot, in 16th- or 17th-century ink.

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled in pencil and plummet; pricking on all edges of the page for frame and lines, spaced 5.5 mm apart. Horizontal rules occur from top to bottom (fol. 2r) at 33.5 | 39 | 44.5 | 21.75 | 207 | 212.75 | 273; vertical rules, from left to right, 20 | 24 | 79.5 | 84 | 88.5 | 142 | 146.5 | 191.5. Written above top line.

handDesc.handNote: Gothic textualis, end of the 12th century. Three scribes, with fols. 28vb–30rb, written in a darker shade of ink, likely a slightly later addition.

decoDesc.decoNote: Text opens with an 8-line Arabesque initial in red and green. Subsequent chapters open with 2-line initials, generally alternating between blue and red.

Along with letters added plummet to direct the rubricator, there are numbers whose function is unclear: iii in the margin of fol. 10rb; iii, fol. 17rb; iiii, fol. 17va; iii, fol. 18ra; iiii and viii, fol. 18rb.

binding.p: Standard Digby binding (Delisle type I). Brass clasps.
binding.decoNote: Decorated with Digby’s arms, surrounded by wreath, with legend INSIGNIA KENELMI DIGBY EQVITIS AVRATI ✠.

history.origin: Probably written at St Frideswide’s, Oxford (OSA) while Philip was prior, c.1180–c.1195. It includes what appear to be autograph revisions to the text rather than corrections from an exemplar, most notably in his account of the translation of Frideswide’s relics on fol. 2ra, and what appears to be an extended addition at the foot of fols. 15v–16r. The text at fols. 28vb–30rb appears to be a slightly later addition. The series of nine readings in the margins suggest extended liturgical use that would not likely have occurred outside of Oxford.
history.provenance: Thomas Allen (no. 7, folio); Allen/Digby inventory A 14: pressmarks and signature on fol. 1r. Many of Allen’s manuscripts were from Oxford.
history.acquisition: Given to the Bodleian by Kenelm Digby (his motto, Vindica te tibi, and signature on fol. 1r).
